sen.j: 建武以来追加（けんむいらいついか）とは、室町幕府が制定した追加法の法令集。
sen.e: Kenmu Irai Tsuika refers to the supplementary law code established by Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Kenmu Irai Tsuika refers to the supplementary law code established by Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).
Kenmu Irai Tsuika refers to the supplementary law code established by Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: その名称から室町幕府の基本法とされる建武式目（建武 (日本)3年（1336年）制定）の追加と考えられがちである。
sen.e: Because of its name, one may consider it supplemental to the Kenmu Code (established in 1336), which is thought to be the fundamental law of the Muromachi bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Because of its name, one may consider it supplemental to the Kenmu Code (established in 1336), which is thought to be the fundamental law of the Muromachi bakufu.
Because of its name, one may consider it supplemental to the Kenmu Code (established in 1336), which is thought to be the fundamental law of the Muromachi bakufu.

sen.j: しかし、室町幕府は建武式目も鎌倉幕府の基本法であった御成敗式目の追加法であるという立場を取っている。
sen.e: However, Muromachi bakufu considered that Kenmu Code was also supplemental to Goseibai Shikimoku, which was the fundamental law of the Kamakura bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, Muromachi bakufu considered the Kenmu Code was also supplemental to Goseibai Shikimoku, which was the fundamental law of the Kamakura bakufu.
However, Muromachi bakufu considered the Kenmu Code was also supplemental to Goseibai Shikimoku, which was the fundamental law of the Kamakura bakufu.

sen.j: 建武以来追加も建武式目以後に追加された御成敗式目の追加法という立場に立ったものである。
sen.e: Kenmu Irai Tsuika was established as supplemental of Goseibai Shikimoku that was added to Goseibai Shikimoku after the Kenmu Code.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Kenmu Irai Tsuika was established supplemental to Goseibai Shikimoku and was added to Goseibai Shikimoku after the Kenmu Code.
Kenmu Irai Tsuika was established supplemental to Goseibai Shikimoku and was added to Goseibai Shikimoku after the Kenmu Code.

sen.j: 数回にわたって編纂され、諸本が多く存在する。
sen.e: It had been compiled several times, and various books have been found.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: It had been compiled several times, and various books have been found.
It had been compiled several times, and various books have been found.

sen.j: 現存する諸本より、文明 (日本)・永正・大永期に増補編纂が行われたことが確認できる。
sen.e: Based on various existing books, it have been confirmed that the law code had been revised and enlarged in Bunmei, Eisho and Taiei era.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: Based on the various existing books, it has been confirmed that the law code had been revised and enlarged in Bunmei, Eisho, and Taiei era.
Based on the various existing books, it has been confirmed that the law code had been revised and enlarged in Bunmei (1469 to 1486), Eisho and Taiei era (1504 to 1527).

sen.j: また、応永・文安・長禄年間にも編纂が行われたと推定されている。
sen.e: Moreover, it is presumed that the law code had been compiled during Oei, Bunan, and Choroku era.
Moreover, it is presumed that the law code had been compiled during Oei, Bunan, and the Choroku era.
Moreover, it is presumed that the law code had been compiled during Oei (1394 to 1427), Bunan (1444 to 1448), and the Choroku (1457 to 1461) era.

sen.j: 最終版とされる大永版には建武5年（1338年）より永正17年（1520年）までの法令が年代順に採録されている。
sen.e: In the Taiei edition, which is regarded as the final edition, the statutes from 1338 to 1520 were recorded by chronological order.
In the Taiei edition, which is regarded as the final edition, the statutes from 1338 to 1520 were recorded in chronological order.
In the Taiei edition, which is regarded as the final edition, the statutes from 1338 to 1520 were recorded in chronological order.

sen.j: 初期のものには寺社・本所関係、守護・地頭関係など全国的な広がりを持つ法令が多い。
sen.e: In the early days, many statutes regulated nationwide matters, such as temples, shrines, honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor), shugo (provincial constable), and jito (manager and lord of manor).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In the early days, many statutes regulated nationwide matters, such as temples, shrines, honjo (proprietor or guarantor of manor), shugo (provincial constable), and jito (manager and lord of manor).

In the early days, many statutes regulated nationwide matters, such as temples, shrines, honjo (the administrative headquarters of a shoen), shugo (provincial constable), and jito (manager and lord of manor).
sen.cmt: 用語補足を修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、守護領国制の展開と政治・財政基盤の京都及びその周辺への依存が高まるにつれて徳政令などの経済法が増加する。
sen.e: However, the economic statutes, such as Tokuseirei, increased as deployment of Shugo-ryogoku system (the system that a Shugo dominates a manor), and as politics and corporate finances depended more on Kyoto and vicinity.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: However, economic statutes, such as Tokuseirei, increased as deployment of Shugo-ryogoku system (the system whereby a Shugo dominates a manor), and as politics and corporate finances depended more on Kyoto and vicinity.

However, economic statutes, such as Tokuseirei (ordering return of land sold and dissolution of debts), increased as deployment of Shugo-ryogoku system (the system whereby a Shugo dominates a manor), and as politics and corporate finances depended more on Kyoto and vicinity.

sen.j: また仮名交じり文の法令が増加するようになる。
sen.e: In addition, the statutes written in both kanji and kana increased.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。
sen.e: In addition, the statutes written in both kanji and kana increased.
In addition, the statutes written in both kanji and kana (the Japanese syllabary) increased.
